channel.title: NYT > Chess
channel.description: News about Chess, including commentary and archival articles published in The New York Times.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Two European Events Could Scramble Rankings
item.description: Most of the world’s top players descended on Europe to compete in either the Candidates tournament or the European Individual Chess Championship.
item.author: By DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

item.title: League Play Pays Off for a Former Champ, Too
item.description: Viswanathan Anand has a special relationship with Germany’s Budesliga, a lucrative source of income for players trying to earn a living at chess.
item.author: By DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

item.title: A Player’s Attacks Pay Off at a Tournament in Minsk
item.description: Baadur Jobava of the republic of Georgia won the International Open Tournament, an event held in honor of one of the greatest players of the 20th century.
item.author: By DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

item.title: Princeton a Repeat Champ at Amateur Tournament
item.description: Princeton University’s “A” squad was only the second team to ever win the Amateur Team East championship two years in a row, and the last time that happened was in the mid-1970s.
item.author: By DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

item.title: After Unexpected Climb Into Playoff, Bulgarian Is King of the Rock
item.description: Ivan Cheparinov, who was ranked as No. 17 in the tournament field, won a playoff to take the crown at the Tradewise Gibraltar Chess Festival.
item.author: By DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

item.title: Magnus Carlsen Picks Up Where He Left Off
item.description: He won the world title in November, but then skipped some of his favorite tournaments before coming back to win the Zurich Chess Challenge last week.
item.author: By DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

item.title: Intrigue, Conspiracy, Alien Abduction: Politics of Chess Go Off the Board
item.description: The intrigue revolves around corruption allegations by the two candidates for the federation’s presidency, Garry Kasparov, the former champion and Russian opposition figure, and Kirsan Ilyumzhinov, the incumbent president.
item.author: By DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

item.title: World’s No. 2 Player Ready to Challenge for the Top Spot
item.description: Levon Aronian dominated the Tata Steel Chess Tournament last week and may get a chance to take on the world titleholder, Magnus Carlsen, in the fall.
item.author: By DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

item.title: From Novice Prison Player to Hero of the Big Screen
item.description: The new movie “Life of a King” is based on the experiences of Eugene Brown, an ex-convict who learned the game in prison and now operates a chess center for children in Washington.
item.author: By DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

item.title: Magnus Carlsen, Chess Champion: ‘My Moves Speak for Themselves’
item.description: The Norwegian 23-year-old on intimidating (and dating) the competition.
item.author: Interview by SUSAN DOMINUS
